prompt: Plans to convert a disused underground bunker into a music centre have been backed by Wiltshire councillors.
HWT: Harnham bunker, officially known as Salisbury Urban District Control Centre, has been empty for years. Youth group The Sound Emporium plans to convert it into its new base and said, being underground with thick walls, it's the ideal place for a music venue. But concerns were raised about potential noise, vibration and litter by some of those living nearby. Council officers advised the impact would not be "unduly harmful" and there were also letters of support. The plans for a change of use were approved at a meeting of Wiltshire Council's southern area planning committee on Thursday. Ross Sanderson, of the Sound Emporium, told the BBC the venue was "unique" and "inspiring". "What better place to have a music venue than underground, with the natural soundproofing of the earth plus between 5ft-10ft thick concrete walls?" Salisbury City Council owns the bunker, once an old military telephone exchange which became the council's control centre in 1963. The bunker still has some of its old typewriters and fittings - and an escape hatch.
MGT:
Wiltshire councillors have given the green light to proposals for a new music centre housed within a disused underground bunker. The ambitious project aims to transform the once-secret Cold War relic into a vibrant hub for musicians and music enthusiasts.

The bunker, located just outside of Devizes, has been derelict for decades. Developers envision a state-of-the-art facility boasting multiple rehearsal rooms, a recording studio, and a performance space capable of hosting small concerts and workshops.

Supporters of the plan highlight its potential to boost the local economy and provide much-needed resources for aspiring musicians in the region. Concerns regarding noise pollution from the site were addressed in the planning application, with assurances that soundproofing measures would be implemented to minimize any disruption to nearby residents.

The conversion is expected to create several new jobs and attract visitors from across the county. Funding for the project is expected to come from a combination of private investment and public grants. Construction is slated to begin in the coming months, with the music centre anticipated to open its doors within the next two years.

prompt: Gary Locke has left his post as Cowdenbeath manager to become an ambassador for Hearts, with Billy Brown named the Blue Brazil's new boss.
HWT: Locke was in charge at Central Park for the second half of last term and guided the club to a play-off win over East Kilbride that kept them in League Two. Brown, who has worked alongside Locke in the past, helped out at Cowden towards the end of last season. The club say their aim remains to secure promotion next season. Cowdenbeath chairman Donald Findlay told the club website: "I am sorry to see Gary leave. However, in his time at Central Park we have become friends and I always made it plain to him that I would not stand in his way if the opportunity came along to join a bigger club. "I am well aware of his affection for Hearts, who have acted with absolute propriety in this matter, as I would expect. I will always be grateful for what he and Billy Brown did for the club at the end of the season and I have every confidence that Billy will carry on the good work." Locke, who becomes the Tynecastle outfit's principal ambassador, is taking up the post in the "club's commercial department" and will also "work alongside director of football Craig Levein in assisting to monitor the numerous loan players the club have across the country". The 42-year-old, who played for Hearts from 1992-2001, also managed the Edinburgh side in the 2013-14 season. Hearts chairwoman Ann Budge told the club's website: "We are thrilled that Gary is back working with us in such an important role."
MGT:
Gary Locke has departed his role as manager of Cowdenbeath to take up an ambassadorial position with Heart of Midlothian. The move brings an end to Locke's tenure at Central Park, which began in December 2022.

Cowdenbeath announced the departure on Tuesday, expressing gratitude for Locke's service to the club. During his time in charge, Locke guided the Blue Brazil through a challenging period, working to stabilize the team and develop young talent.

Locke's connection with Hearts is deeply rooted, having previously served as a player, coach, and manager at Tynecastle. His return to the club in an ambassadorial role is expected to be a popular move with the Hearts support. The specific duties of his new role are yet to be fully defined, but it is understood that he will be involved in community outreach, commercial activities, and representing the club at various events.

Meanwhile, Cowdenbeath have acted swiftly to appoint Billy Brown as their new manager. Brown brings a wealth of experience to the role, having previously held coaching positions at several clubs, including Hearts, Hibernian, and Raith Rovers. He has also managed Brechin City.

Brown's appointment is seen as a positive step for Cowdenbeath, as they look to build on the foundations laid by Locke. He is known for his tactical acumen and ability to motivate players, and the club will be hoping that he can quickly make an impact at Central Park.

Cowdenbeath chairman, in a statement, welcomed Brown to the club, highlighting his experience and knowledge of the Scottish game. He also thanked Locke for his dedication and wished him well in his new role at Hearts. Brown is expected to take charge of his first game this weekend.

prompt: Cuba returned to the United States an inert Hellfire missile that had been wrongly shipped to Havana in June 2014.
HWT: The missile, which did not contain explosives, had been shipped to Spain for a Nato training exercise, the Wall Street Journal said. It was then taken to Germany and eventually to Charles de Gaulle Airport in Paris for onward delivery to Florida. It was instead loaded on to an Air France flight to Havana. The incident could have led to a serious loss of military technology, officials told the Wall Street Journal. The whole affair has been embarrassing for the Americans, who have had to ask the Cubans if they could have their highly sensitive missile back, says the BBC's Will Grant in Havana. The missile arrived on a flight from Paris "by mistake or mishandling in the country of origin," said a Cuban Foreign Ministry statement. "Cuba acted with seriousness and transparency and co-operated to find a satisfactory solution to this issue," it added. The AGM 114 Hellfire is a laser-guided missile that can be deployed from an attack helicopter or an unmanned drone. US officials were worried that Cuba could share the advanced technology inside the missile with countries such as North Korea, China or Russia, sources close to the investigation told the Wall Street Journal. The US and Cuba, old Cold War enemies, restored diplomatic relations in July last year after more than 50 years. The two countries have been working to rebuild their economic and trade ties. An announcement is expected on Tuesday about the reinstatement of scores of commercial flights between US cities and Havana.
MGT:
After a prolonged period of diplomatic negotiations, Cuba has returned to the United States an inert Hellfire missile that was mistakenly delivered to Havana in June 2014. The return of the missile, which occurred recently, marks the closure of a sensitive chapter in relations between the two nations.

The Hellfire missile, a sophisticated piece of U.S. military technology, was shipped to Cuba in error, sparking concerns within the U.S. government about the potential compromise of sensitive technology. The incident triggered a high-level effort to secure the missile's return, involving diplomatic channels and security agencies.

U.S. officials expressed relief that the missile had been recovered. The U.S. government had been concerned that the Cuban government might share the technology with other countries, including rivals or adversaries of the United States.

The Cuban government maintained throughout the ordeal that it had no intention of sharing the missile with third parties. Cuban officials stated that they had promptly informed the United States about the mistaken delivery and expressed their willingness to cooperate in resolving the matter.

The return of the missile comes at a time when relations between the United States and Cuba have experienced periods of both progress and tension. The two countries restored diplomatic relations in 2015 after decades of estrangement, but subsequent administrations have adopted varying approaches to engagement with the island nation.

The successful recovery of the missile may contribute to a more positive atmosphere between the two countries. It demonstrates the potential for cooperation on matters of mutual concern, even amidst broader disagreements. Both governments have expressed a desire to continue dialogue on issues of security and regional stability. The incident serves as a reminder of the complexities and sensitivities involved in international relations.

prompt: The sequel to 2009 hit Avatar has been delayed a year and will not be released until 2017, James Cameron has revealed.
HWT: The Oscar-winning director of Aliens and Titanic said he is working on three new Avatar films at the same time. The first film was supposed to be out in December 2016, but Cameron said writing the stories had become "very involved". "There's a layer of complexity in getting the story to work as a saga across three films," he explained. Cameron said the goal was to have the scripts for the three movies completed by the end of this month so that filming can begin. "We're writing three simultaneously and we've done that so that everything tracks throughout the three films," he told the Associated Press. "We're not just going to do one and then make up another one and another one after that. "And parallel with that, we're doing all the design. So we've designed all the creatures and the environments." Cameron said he thought it was important that each film linked forward to the next one in a satisfying way, but also came to a resolution that did not leave the audience hanging. The three films will be shot in New Zealand, where some of the original film was also made. Avatar is the highest-grossing film in history, with box office takings of almost $2.8 billion (Â£1.8 billion). Set in the 22nd Century on a distant planet inhabited by a humanoid race, the sci-fi epic went on to win three Oscars. Cameron, 60, was speaking at an event in Wellington on Wednesday to promote the New Zealand film industry.
MGT:
Fans eagerly awaiting the return to Pandora will have to exercise patience. James Cameron has announced that the highly anticipated sequel to his groundbreaking 2009 film, Avatar, has been pushed back a year. The film, originally slated for a 2016 release, will now grace screens in 2017.

The delay, while disappointing for many, is attributed to the ambitious scope of the project. Cameron, known for his meticulous attention to detail and groundbreaking visual effects, is reportedly aiming to surpass the original Avatar in terms of technological innovation and immersive storytelling.

"There's a lot involved in bringing these films to life," Cameron stated in a recent interview. "We want to deliver something truly special, something that lives up to the expectations and continues the story in a meaningful way."

The original Avatar, a cinematic marvel that captivated audiences worldwide, revolutionized 3D filmmaking and set a new standard for visual effects. The film's immersive world, compelling narrative, and environmental themes resonated deeply with viewers, propelling it to become the highest-grossing film of all time.

The sequel promises to delve deeper into the vibrant ecosystem of Pandora, exploring new regions and introducing new cultures of the Na'vi people. Cameron has hinted at underwater sequences that will showcase the breathtaking beauty and diversity of Pandora's oceans.

While the delay may test the patience of fans, Cameron and his team are committed to delivering an unforgettable cinematic experience. The additional time will allow them to refine the visual effects, polish the script, and ensure that the sequel lives up to the legacy of the original Avatar. The world of Pandora awaits, and while the journey may take a little longer, the destination promises to be well worth the wait.

prompt: A charity whose office was destroyed when a bus ploughed into it has a new home after a fortnight of staff working on laptops and mobile devices.
HWT: Thirteen people were hurt when the single-decker hit the building used by Guide Dogs UK in the centre of Peterborough on Christmas Eve. The charity has moved into an office in the Orton Southgate area of the city. Helen Sismore, community engagement manager, said: "We should be back in our repaired office by April." The bus went through the bay windows on the front of the charity's regional office on Broadway. Passengers had a variety of minor injuries but no-one was injured in the office where three people were in back rooms. Ms Sismore said: "We heard and felt the crash and it was horrific and the timing on Christmas Eve didn't help. "We've been working using laptops wherever we can find wi-fi, such as our homes, cafes and libraries. "No clients have suffered because we've been in telephone contact using our mobiles and we've had a lot of support from our volunteers and the local community." She said the repair of the rented Broadway offices was being covered by the landlord's insurance and they were renting the temporary office on Cully Court at the market rate.
MGT:
After a challenging two weeks, a local charity has found a new home following the destruction of its office by a bus accident. Staff members, displaced by the incident, have been working remotely on laptops and mobile devices to maintain essential services.

The charity, which provides support to vulnerable individuals and families, expressed relief and gratitude to the community for the outpouring of support they received. "The last two weeks have been incredibly difficult, but the dedication of our staff and the generosity of the public have been overwhelming," said a spokesperson for the organization.

The new office space, secured with the help of local businesses and volunteers, will allow the charity to resume its full range of programs and services. While the organization is still assessing the full extent of the damage to its previous location, the focus remains on ensuring uninterrupted support for its clients.

The charity is now appealing for donations to help furnish the new office and replace equipment lost in the accident. They are also seeking volunteers to assist with the move and set-up of the new space. The organization anticipates being fully operational in the new location within the coming days.

prompt: A man who defrauded a 98-year-old woman he befriended of £170,000 has been jailed for five years and one month.
HWT: Russell Joy, 45, of Shapwick, Dorset, set up direct debits, withdrew money and cashed bonds on behalf of Mary Brady, from Broadstone. Bournemouth Crown Court heard Joy won the trust of the pensioner, who died earlier this month, when she hired him as her gardener in 2008. He was entrusted to withdraw money for her daily living expenses. In December 2014 he made the first of 107 withdrawals without her knowledge, totalling £32,100. The following November Ms Brady cashed five bonds in the sum of £230,000 and wrote Joy a cheque for £100,000. In March 2016, he received a further £20,000 cheque. He also withdrew money to buy a Land Rover car and set up a direct debit to pay his vehicle insurance. The offences came to light when the pensioner's relatives checked her finances while she was in hospital. In a statement, Ms Brady's family said they were "desperately sad" about the "ugly end" to her life. Det Insp Andy Dilworth said: "Russell Joy is nothing more than a callous fraudster. He befriended his victim over a period of many years and quickly earned her trust." He said Joy ,who pleaded guilty at a previous hearing to six counts of fraud by abuse of position, would be subject to action under the Proceeds of Crime Act.
MGT:
A 41-year-old man has been sentenced to five years and one month in prison for defrauding a vulnerable 98-year-old woman of a substantial sum of money. The man, who befriended the elderly woman, exploited her trust to gain access to her finances, ultimately defrauding her of £170,000.

The court heard how the man initially presented himself as a helpful and supportive companion to the woman, who lived alone. Over time, he gradually gained her confidence, offering assistance with errands and household tasks. This cultivated relationship allowed him to subtly manipulate her into granting him control over her financial affairs.

Prosecutors revealed that the man systematically siphoned funds from the woman's bank accounts over a period of several months. He used the money for his own personal gain, including lavish purchases and gambling. The fraud was only discovered when a concerned family member noticed discrepancies in the woman's bank statements.

The judge presiding over the case condemned the man's actions, describing them as "despicable and predatory." He emphasized the severity of the crime, highlighting the vulnerability of the victim and the significant emotional and financial impact the fraud had on her life. The judge noted that the sentence reflected the gravity of the offense and served as a deterrent to others who might consider exploiting elderly or vulnerable individuals.

The victim's family expressed relief at the sentence, stating that it brought a sense of justice after a difficult and distressing ordeal. They also expressed gratitude to the authorities for their thorough investigation and prosecution of the case. The family hopes that this case will raise awareness about the importance of safeguarding vulnerable individuals from financial abuse.

prompt: Protesting opposition MPs in Kosovo have released tear gas in parliament for the sixth time in just over two months, disrupting a vote on the government's 2016 budget.
HWT: Outside, opposition supporters threw stones and smashed windows before they were dispersed by riot police. Protesters have been trying to disrupt parliament over an EU-brokered deal to improve relations with Serbia. Kosovo unilaterally declared its independence from Serbia in 2008. The opposition first released tear gas in parliament on 8 October, causing two MPs to faint. US Secretary of State John Kerry, on a visit to the capital, Pristina, earlier this month, called for an end to violent scenes in parliament, saying it was "not the place for tear gas and... not the place for intimidation". However, opposition MPs released gas canisters again in the parliamentary chamber on Monday, forcing a suspension of proceedings. A large group of plainclothes police officers donned gas masks as the chamber was cleared. One of the MPs who released the gas, Glauk Konjufca, said it was "a collective action by the opposition". "Others have done this too, and we will continue to do this in the future. Our breaching of the law is nothing compared to the damage that is being done by these agreements." The opposition is particularly opposed to a deal to give more autonomy to Kosovo's ethnic Serb minority, which they say could increase Serbia's influence. The vote on next year's €1.67bn (£1.1bn) budget resumed in a side room, with only MPs from the governing coalition present and was approved, Reuters news agency reported. The US ambassador to Kosovo, Greg Delawie, condemned the disorder, saying it was "very disappointing" that Mr Kerry's calls had gone unheeded.
MGT:
PRISTINA - Kosovo's parliament was once again engulfed in chaos on Friday as opposition members released tear gas, disrupting a crucial vote on the 2016 budget. This marks the sixth time in just over two months that such disruptive tactics have been employed by the protesting MPs.

The incident occurred as lawmakers were preparing to debate and vote on the government's proposed budget for the upcoming year. Opposition MPs, vehemently opposed to a series of agreements with Serbia and Montenegro, initiated their protest by releasing tear gas canisters within the parliamentary chamber.

The noxious fumes quickly filled the room, forcing lawmakers to evacuate and halting the proceedings. Many MPs were seen coughing and covering their faces as they rushed to escape the tear gas.

The opposition's actions are rooted in their strong disapproval of a deal brokered with Serbia, granting greater autonomy to Serb-populated areas in Kosovo. They also oppose a border demarcation agreement with Montenegro, claiming it cedes valuable Kosovar territory.

These agreements, supported by the government, are seen by the opposition as a betrayal of Kosovo's sovereignty and national interests. They have vowed to continue disrupting parliamentary sessions until the agreements are revoked.

The government has condemned the opposition's actions, calling them undemocratic and harmful to the country's stability. Prime Minister Isa Mustafa has accused the opposition of resorting to violence and obstructionism to achieve their political goals.

The repeated use of tear gas in parliament has created a climate of instability and uncertainty in Kosovo. It has also raised concerns about the country's ability to function as a democratic institution.

International observers have expressed concern over the ongoing political crisis and have urged both the government and the opposition to engage in constructive dialogue to resolve their differences. They have also called on all parties to respect the rule of law and to refrain from violence and disruptive tactics.

The parliamentary session has been adjourned, and it is unclear when the vote on the budget will be rescheduled. The political crisis in Kosovo continues to deepen, with no immediate solution in sight.

prompt: Manufacturing sales from Northern Ireland were worth £13.3bn last year, the highest value on record.
HWT: External sales were up by 3.2% over the year, a rise of £415m. The biggest market for those goods is Great Britain which accounts for £8.1bn - just under half the total value. The Republic of Ireland is the next single biggest market at £1.3bn, followed by the rest of the EU at £1.2bn. Sales to all other parts of the world were £2.6bn. The figures suggest that Northern Ireland manufacturing may be benefiting from the recoveries in the wider British and Irish economies. Sales to GB were up by 6.2% while sales to the Republic of Ireland were up by 5.3%. However sales to other EU countries fell by 13%. The figures are produced by the  Northern Ireland Statistics and Research Agency (NISRA). Richard Ramsey Ulster Bank chief economist in Northern Ireland said one of the key themes from the figures is the growing importance of the GB market for NI's manufacturing firms. He said: "Whilst there have been huge efforts by policymakers to encourage local firms to export to markets outside of the UK, Great Britain has been the fastest growing market for NI's manufacturers following the downturn. "Since 2007/08, NI's manufacturing sales to GB have increased by almost one quarter (+23%) or £1.5bn. "In 2012/13 NI's manufacturers sold six times more goods, in value terms, to the GB market than they did to the Republic of Ireland. "Back in 2007/08,  local manufacturers sold just over three times more goods to the GB market than they exported to the Republic of Ireland."
MGT:
Manufacturing sales in Northern Ireland have reached an unprecedented high, hitting £13.3 billion in the past year. This marks a significant milestone for the region's manufacturing sector, showcasing its resilience and growth potential in a challenging global economic landscape. The record-breaking figures underscore the sector's vital contribution to Northern Ireland's overall economy and employment.

Several factors have contributed to this surge in manufacturing sales. Increased demand for Northern Ireland's products in both domestic and international markets has played a crucial role. The region's manufacturers have successfully capitalized on emerging opportunities, particularly in sectors such as aerospace, food and drink, and advanced engineering.

Furthermore, investments in innovation and technology have enhanced the competitiveness of Northern Ireland's manufacturing firms. By embracing new technologies and adopting advanced manufacturing processes, these companies have been able to improve efficiency, reduce costs, and develop higher-value products. This has enabled them to attract new customers and expand their market share.

Government support and initiatives have also played a key role in fostering the growth of the manufacturing sector. Targeted programs aimed at promoting innovation, skills development, and export opportunities have provided valuable assistance to local manufacturers. These initiatives have helped to create a more favorable business environment and encourage investment in the sector.

The record-breaking manufacturing sales figures are expected to have a positive impact on the Northern Ireland economy. The increased revenue generated by the sector will contribute to higher tax receipts, which can be used to fund public services and infrastructure projects. Moreover, the growth of the manufacturing sector is likely to create new employment opportunities, benefiting local communities and reducing unemployment rates.

Looking ahead, the manufacturing sector in Northern Ireland is poised for continued growth. With a strong foundation in place and a commitment to innovation, local manufacturers are well-positioned to capitalize on future opportunities. However, it is important to address ongoing challenges such as skills shortages and supply chain disruptions to ensure the sector's long-term sustainability.

prompt: A racehorse has survived a two-hour swim, covering 11km, after being scared during a training run on a beach in Brisbane, Australia.
HWT: Rebel Rover was being trained in chest-high water at Sandgate beach when he unseated his rider and headed deeper. The five-year-old gelding was picked up by the Brisbane Water Police and a marine rescue unit. "He was in about four metres of water and he was swimming quite freely," said Volunteer Marine Rescue's Glen Philip. Rebel Rover, with a track record of misdemeanours, has only recently made a comeback after being banned for misbehaving in the stalls. Trainer Brad Smith told ABC News that horses could swim, but did not normally do so very much. "Any other horse, 20 minutes would probably see them out, but this horse - he must have a pretty amazing lung capacity," he said. "The vet looked at him yesterday and again this morning and he's pretty well amazed with how he's coped with it all. Brisbane's Courier Mail reports he still had enough energy to head butt one of his support team, knocking them unconscious and putting them in hospital. Rebel Rover has won three of his 12 races.
MGT:
A racehorse has defied the odds, surviving a remarkable two-hour swim after being spooked during a training session on a Brisbane beach. The incident occurred early Tuesday morning when the thoroughbred, named 'Courageous Comet' by stablehands online, was undergoing routine exercise along the shoreline.

According to witnesses, a sudden noise, possibly a low-flying aircraft, startled the animal, causing it to bolt into the ocean. Despite attempts by the trainer to regain control, Courageous Comet swam further out to sea.

A large-scale rescue operation was launched, involving local marine authorities, including jet skis and boats. After two hours, the exhausted horse was finally located approximately 11 kilometers from the shore.

"We were incredibly worried. Horses aren't built for long-distance swimming," said a spokesperson for the Queensland Racing Association. "It's a testament to the horse's strength and will to survive that it made it through."

Courageous Comet was carefully coaxed onto a specialized vessel and transported back to land, where a veterinarian was waiting. The horse is currently under observation and is reported to be in stable condition, suffering mainly from exhaustion. The incident has sparked discussions about safety protocols during beach training sessions.

prompt: Trainer Kevin Ryan has been suspended from running horses after a case of equine herpes was found at his yard.
HWT: Only one case has been discovered in Ryan's string but the yard near Thirsk has been placed under quarantine by the British Horseracing Authority (BHA). The nearby stables of trainers Bryan Smart and Michael Herrington have also been quarantined as a precaution. The BHA said they are working with Ryan and staff to ensure the correct disease control measures are in place. "The risk of the virus being transmitted in a controlled race-day environment is relatively small," said David Sykes, the BHA's director of equine health and welfare. "[But] it is in theory possible that horses from the yard in question may have been infectious some time before the disease was diagnosed. "For this reason we have taken measures to alert trainers, as well as racecourses and veterinary surgeons, to be vigilant to the clinical signs." The equine herpes virus can cause respiratory disease and abort foetuses, while a less common neurological form of the virus can cause co-ordination problems and paralysis, and is potentially fatal. The National Stud breeding site in Newmarket was closed last year following the discovery of the neurological herpes virus infection. Ryan won the French Derby and Irish Champion Stakes in 2014 with The Grey Gatsby and is a four-time winner of the Ayr Gold Cup, including the 2016 edition with Brando.
MGT:
Yorkshire-based racehorse trainer Kevin Ryan has been temporarily suspended from entering horses in races following the confirmed detection of Equine Herpesvirus (EHV-1) at his Hambleton Lodge stables. The British Horseracing Authority (BHA) has implemented the precautionary measure to contain the potential spread of the highly contagious virus.

Ryan, a prominent figure in the racing world, expressed his disappointment and is fully cooperating with veterinary authorities to manage the situation. All horses at Hambleton Lodge are currently undergoing testing and are being closely monitored for any signs of illness.

EHV-1 can cause a range of symptoms in horses, including respiratory issues, neurological problems, and abortion in pregnant mares. Its rapid transmission necessitates swift action to prevent outbreaks from escalating and affecting the wider racing community.

The BHA’s swift response aims to minimize the risk of further spread. Movement restrictions have been put in place at the yard, preventing any horses from leaving the premises until cleared by veterinary officials. Neighboring stables are also being closely monitored as a preventative measure.

The length of Ryan's suspension remains uncertain and depends on the outcome of ongoing testing and the successful implementation of biosecurity protocols at Hambleton Lodge. The BHA will reassess the situation regularly and provide updates as more information becomes available. The racing industry is acutely aware of the potential disruption caused by EHV-1 outbreaks and remains vigilant in its efforts to protect equine health.

prompt: The Environment Agency is reviewing the flood risk around the English coastline from high waves.
HWT: It says some of its existing maps may underestimate the risks to coastal communities. It is updating its National Flood Risk Assessment which informs members of the public and local authorities about the likelihood of flooding. The Environment Agency grades coastal areas at risk of flooding from very low to high. Environment Agency flood risks: High: Greater than one in 30 chance in any given year Medium: One in 30 to one in 200 chance in any given year Low: One in 200 to one in 1000 chance in any given year Very low: Less than one in 1,000 chance in any given year Last winter massive storms hit the South West coast with waves up to 15m (50ft) high, destroying part of the main railway line out of the region at Dawlish. Marcus Salmon, planning liaison technical specialist with the agency, said: "The storms have definitely reflected areas where our maps are not as representative as they can be. "That is something that we are working to address as quickly as possible. "Last winter's storms showed the susceptibility of our coastal communities and infrastructure to flooding and erosion. "The challenges presented by flooding and coastal erosion are expected to become more acute as a result of climate change, due to a combination of sea level rise, increased storminess and increased wave heights. "So as to better understand the risks we are updating the National Flood Risk Assessment to take account of wave, wind and storm surge which are underrepresented in our current mapping."
MGT:
The Environment Agency has initiated a comprehensive review of flood risk along the English coastline, focusing specifically on the impact of high waves. This assessment comes amid growing concerns about the potential for more frequent and intense coastal flooding due to climate change and rising sea levels.

The review will encompass a detailed analysis of existing coastal defenses, including sea walls, embankments, and natural barriers, to determine their effectiveness in mitigating the risks posed by increasingly powerful wave action. It will also incorporate advanced modeling techniques to project future wave heights and patterns, taking into account various climate change scenarios.

Experts will examine vulnerable coastal communities and infrastructure, identifying areas most susceptible to wave-induced flooding. This will involve assessing the potential damage to homes, businesses, and critical infrastructure such as power plants and transportation networks.

The agency aims to use the findings of the review to inform future coastal management strategies and investment decisions. This could include upgrading existing defenses, constructing new barriers, or implementing nature-based solutions such as restoring coastal wetlands and dunes.

The review will also consider the social and economic impacts of coastal flooding, including displacement of residents, disruption to tourism, and damage to local economies. It will seek to identify ways to enhance community resilience and preparedness, such as improving early warning systems and promoting flood-resistant building practices.

The Environment Agency emphasizes the importance of collaboration with local authorities, coastal communities, and other stakeholders throughout the review process. Public consultations and engagement events will be held to gather input and ensure that the findings reflect the concerns and priorities of those most affected by coastal flooding. The review is expected to be completed within the next year, with its findings informing a revised national coastal flood risk management strategy.

prompt: A young Syrian man has gone on trial in Germany, accused of being deployed by so-called Islamic State to scope out potential targets in Berlin for attack.
HWT: Identified under German privacy laws as Shaas al-M, he claimed asylum in August 2015 and is now 20 years old. Federal prosecutors say before that he fought with the Islamist militants for two years in his home country. He is being tried by a special security court in Berlin, but reports suggest he refused to testify. He has been in custody since his arrest on 22 March. Shaas al-M's trial comes two weeks after Anis Amri ploughed a truck into a Christmas market in Berlin, killing 12 people. IS later released a video showing him pledging allegiance to its leader Abu-Bakr al-Baghdadi. A year of terror in Germany Berlin attack: Islamic State claims responsibility How attacks are forcing Germany to examine civil freedoms Dressed in a blue pullover and a black cap, he hid his face behind a folder as he took his seat in the courtroom, reported AFP news agency. Officers armed with machine guns were stationed outside the court. Shaas al-M faces charges of being a member of a foreign terrorist organisation, which carries up to 10 years in jail, and violating laws governing military weapons. In a previous statement (in German), the court detailed allegations of Shaas al-M's involvement in IS operations in Syria, including participating in the siege of the airport at Deir al-Zour, handling a Kalashnikov gun and helping supply fighters with food. Once he had arrived in Germany, he maintained intensive contact with IS superiors, it says, and began to undertake visits to Berlin where he explored landmarks including Alexanderplatz, the Brandenburg Gate and the Reichstag parliament building, reporting his findings back to his contacts. He is also accused of arranging for at least one person to travel to Syria to fight, and offering his services to assist would-be attackers travelling to Germany. The court has scheduled some 25 hearings to run until April.
MGT:
BERLIN - A 21-year-old Syrian man appeared in a Berlin court today, facing charges of espionage and supporting a foreign terrorist organization. The prosecution alleges that the man, identified only as Mazen G. due to German privacy laws, was tasked by the Islamic State (ISIS) to gather intelligence on potential targets in the German capital.

Prosecutors contend that Mazen G. traveled to Germany in 2022, ostensibly as a refugee, but in reality, he was on a mission for the extremist group. They claim he received specific instructions from ISIS operatives to identify locations suitable for future terrorist attacks. These locations reportedly included Jewish institutions, government buildings, and transportation hubs.

"Fifteen of the 23 players that took on Ospreys at Parc y Scarlets last week came through, or took some part, in the development pathway." Flanker Macleod, 20, has enjoyed a breakthrough season for Scarlets, including a Champions Cup start against champions Saracens. Former Wales Under-20 captain Phillips, 21, made his professional debut against Zebre in October 2015 and the blindside flanker has since gone on to make 14 appearances for the west Wales region. Centre Hughes, 23, is another former Wales U20 captain and has battled back from a serious knee injury to make 17 appearances this season in the Champions Cup and Guinness Pro12. Lock Price, 24, joined Scarlets in the summer of 2015 from Leicester Tigers, making his competitive debut in the season opener against Glasgow in September of the same year. The 6ft 8in Wales-qualified second row has made 35 appearances for the Scarlets to date, scoring three tries. "These four players join an exciting group who have already committed their futures to the region, alongside Steff Evans, Will Boyde, Dan Jones and Hadleigh Parkes as well as internationals Rob Evans, Samson Lee and Ken Owens," Daniels added. Scarlets finished third in the Pro12 this season and play Leinster in Dublin on Friday night for a place in the end-of-season play-off final.
MGT:
The Scarlets have secured the services of four key players, announcing contract extensions for forwards Josh Macleod, Tom Phillips, and Tom Price, alongside centre Steffan Hughes. The news provides a significant boost for the Welsh region as they look to build on their recent performances.

Josh Macleod, a dynamic flanker known for his relentless work rate and breakdown expertise, has become a mainstay in the Scarlets' back row. His commitment and physicality have made him a firm favorite with fans and a valuable asset to the squad. Securing his future at Parc y Scarlets is seen as crucial for maintaining the team's competitive edge.

Tom Phillips, another versatile forward capable of playing across the back row, has also committed his future to the region. His experience and leadership qualities are highly valued within the squad, and his ability to cover multiple positions makes him an indispensable member of the team.

Lock Tom Price, brings considerable experience to the Scarlets pack. His aerial prowess in the lineout and his uncompromising defense add significant steel to the Scarlets' forward unit. His continued presence will provide valuable stability and mentorship for younger players coming through the ranks.

Steffan Hughes, a skillful and experienced centre, completes the quartet of contract extensions. Hughes's playmaking ability and defensive solidity make him a key figure in the Scarlets' midfield. His vision and distribution skills are vital for unlocking opposition defenses, and his leadership qualities are also highly respected within the squad.

The re-signing of these four players underscores the Scarlets' commitment to retaining their core talent and building a squad capable of challenging for silverware in the coming seasons. The news will be welcomed by supporters who value the continuity and experience that these players bring to the region.

prompt: A 19th Century engine building used to pump water out of a Denbighshire mine is being restored.
HWT: Clive Engine House has stood unused for more than 120 years after serving Talargoch Mine in Dyserth until 1884. Now county archaeologists have secured funds to repair the building, which has been affected by weathering over the decades. It was opened to the public on Friday to show how work is progressing. Denbighshire council archaeologist Fiona Gale said: "It was a fantastic, once in a lifetime opportunity to repair the building and bring it back into good order". Built in 1860, the Cornish engine house was home to a steam cylinder which powered water extraction pumps. Lead extraction is thought to have taken place at Talargoch since the Roman period. It has also produced copper, silver and calamine, but it is most famous as a producer of lead and zinc ore. The engine house is one of the few remaining signs of what was once a large and important industry in the area. The engine was in operation until the mine closed in 1884 when the engine was sold to the former Westminster Colliery in Wrexham. David Thomas, the Denbighshire cabinet lead member for regeneration, said the building was a "testament to the hard work of all those who worked in the lead mines in the area over many years". Grants from funders WREN and Cadw are paying for repair work which is being co-ordinated by Denbighshire council.
MGT:
Deep within the Denbighshire countryside, a significant piece of industrial heritage is undergoing a meticulous restoration, breathing new life into a 19th-century engine building that once served a vital role in the region's mining history. The structure, originally constructed to house a powerful steam engine, was instrumental in pumping water from the depths of a local mine, enabling the extraction of valuable resources.

For decades, the building stood as a silent sentinel, its purpose forgotten, its walls weathered by the passage of time. However, a dedicated team of conservationists and local historians has embarked on an ambitious project to restore the engine building to its former glory.

The restoration efforts are focused on preserving the building's unique architectural features, including its imposing brickwork, arched windows, and the remnants of the engine's foundations. Skilled craftsmen are employing traditional techniques and materials to repair damaged sections, ensuring the authenticity and longevity of the structure.

The restored engine building is envisioned as a valuable educational resource, offering visitors a glimpse into the region's industrial past. Interpretive displays will showcase the history of the mine, the workings of the steam engine, and the lives of the miners who toiled in its depths.

The project has garnered widespread support from the local community, with residents eager to see this historic landmark revitalized. It is hoped that the restored engine building will serve as a catalyst for further heritage tourism, attracting visitors to the area and boosting the local economy. As the restoration progresses, the building stands as a testament to the ingenuity and hard work of the generations who shaped the industrial landscape of Denbighshire.

prompt: An e-book at the centre of a row over who can use the term "space marine" is back on sale on the Amazon website.
HWT: The Spots the Space Marine story was taken off Amazon after model-soldier maker Games Workshop complained it infringed its trademark on the phrase. A blog post about the row by the story's US author, Maggie Hogarth, led to much criticism for Games Workshop. And digital rights group the Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF) said it had then helped Amazon "review" the case. In a statement about the row, the EFF said it was "outrageous" for Games Workshop to claim any rights over a term that had been in wide use in fiction since the 1930s. It said the case was an example of a growing trend, in which trademark and rights owners targeted the "weakest link" in the chain of people that helped content, be it fiction, movies or music, appear online. Often, said the EFF, the weakest link was an ISP, a hosting company or a website that acted as a store front or aggregator for many different creators. Such "providers usually don't have the resources and/or the inclination to investigate trademark infringement claims", it said. Many simply removed the disputed content immediately to stay "neutral" and avoid trouble, said the EFF, but that made it hard for those on the end of trademark claims to mount a challenge. The online chatter also prompted Games Workshop to put a statement about the row on its Facebook page, in which it said it had "no choice" but to act in cases where its trademarks in a commercially available product were being used without its consent. Despite this, it said, it had never claimed to have rights over the ways in which the terms "warhammer" or "space marine" were used in day-to-day speech. This everyday use also covered a "body of prose", it added. "Trademarks as opposed to use of a word in prose or everyday language are two very different things," it said. "Games Workshop is always vigilant in protecting the former, but never makes any claim to owning the latter."
MGT:
An e-book embroiled in a trademark dispute over the use of the term "space marine" has reappeared for sale on Amazon. The novel, a science fiction title featuring heavily armored warriors in outer space, was temporarily removed from the platform following concerns raised regarding the alleged infringement of intellectual property rights.

The controversy surrounding the term "space marine" has been a long-standing one, primarily involving Games Workshop, the British company renowned for its Warhammer 40,000 tabletop game. Games Workshop has fiercely defended its trademark on "space marine" in various contexts, arguing that the term is inextricably linked to its fictional universe and that its unauthorized use could cause confusion among consumers.

The e-book's return to Amazon's digital shelves suggests that the legal or commercial issues that led to its initial removal have been resolved, at least temporarily. However, the precise nature of the resolution remains unclear. It is possible that an agreement has been reached between the author or publisher of the e-book and Games Workshop, or that Amazon has determined that the specific use of "space marine" in the novel does not constitute a significant infringement.

The debate over the ownership and permissible usage of common terms like "space marine" highlights the complex challenges faced by creators and intellectual property holders in the digital age. While trademark law aims to protect brands and prevent consumer deception, it also needs to be balanced against the principles of free expression and the potential for stifling creativity.

The case has sparked considerable discussion within the science fiction community, with many authors and fans expressing concern about the potential implications for independent creators who may wish to use familiar tropes and terminology in their work. Some argue that aggressively defending trademarks on widely used terms could lead to a chilling effect, discouraging innovation and limiting the range of stories that can be told.

Games Workshop has maintained that its actions are necessary to protect its brand and prevent others from unfairly profiting from its intellectual property. The company has invested heavily in developing the Warhammer 40,000 universe and its associated trademarks, and it believes that it has a right to control how those trademarks are used.

The reappearance of the e-book on Amazon is unlikely to be the end of the story. The legal and commercial landscape surrounding trademark law is constantly evolving, and the debate over the use of "space marine" is likely to continue for some time to come. The outcome of this particular case could have significant implications for authors, publishers, and intellectual property holders across the science fiction genre and beyond.

In the same month, there were 57,000 tourists from the US and 31,600 from France.
MGT:
A hefty restaurant bill presented to a group of Chinese tourists near Jerusalem has ignited a firestorm of controversy online, raising questions about potential overcharging and exploitation of tourists. prompt: Cyprus is lifting the last remaining capital controls it imposed on its banking system during the financial crisis of 2013.
HWT: Cyprus was the only crisis-hit eurozone country to restrict capital transfers, as it faced a run on the banks. The controls were eased in January. There will no longer be a monthly cap of €20,000 (£15,000; $22,000) on transfers by individuals to foreign banks, or of €10,000 for travellers moving money out of the country. Cyprus received a €10bn bailout from the EU and International Monetary Fund (IMF) after its biggest banks nearly collapsed in March 2013 because of huge losses on their Greek investments. The island's second-biggest lender, Cyprus Popular Bank (also known as Laiki Bank), was wound up and deposits worth more than €100,000 in the largest bank, Bank of Cyprus, were seized. Those measures were part of the deal to ensure that Cyprus funded part of the €10bn bailout. Speaking on Friday, Cyprus President Nicos Anastasiades voiced confidence that the Mediterranean island was recovering well, despite three years of recession. Lifting capital controls, he said, was "a vote of confidence in our banking system which, now fully independent of Greek banking institutions, can move forward". The Greek debt crisis had a severe impact on Cypriot banks, which lost about €4.5bn worth of Greek sovereign bonds - equivalent to 25% of Cypriot gross domestic product, Reuters news agency reports.
MGT:
Nicosia, Cyprus - Cyprus is set to fully lift the remaining capital controls that have been in place since the 2013 financial crisis, marking a significant milestone in the country's economic recovery. The restrictions, initially implemented to prevent a run on banks and stabilize the financial system, have been gradually eased over the past several years.

The decision to remove the final restrictions underscores the strengthened resilience of the Cypriot banking sector and the overall improvement in the economic climate. The controls were initially imposed in March 2013, as the country teetered on the brink of financial collapse, requiring a bailout from international lenders.

The restrictions limited the movement of funds both domestically and internationally, impacting businesses and individuals alike. The gradual easing of these measures began in 2015, as confidence in the banking system began to return.

Cypriot officials have credited the successful implementation of economic reforms and prudent fiscal policies for the country's return to financial stability. The lifting of capital controls is expected to further boost investor confidence and attract foreign investment, fostering sustainable economic growth.

The move is also seen as a positive signal to international markets, demonstrating Cyprus' commitment to transparency and adherence to international financial standards. While challenges remain, the complete removal of capital controls represents a symbolic end to a turbulent period in Cypriot history, paving the way for a more prosperous future.

prompt: A teenage demonstrator has been killed during growing unrest in Venezuela, as political and economic crisis deepens.
HWT: The 14-year-old boy and another protester were shot dead in the western city of Barquisimeto on Tuesday night. The local governor blamed armed government supporters. Two students were killed during protests last week. Nicolas Maduro's presidency has come under increasing pressure as the economy suffers and opponents accuse him of creating a dictatorship. Mr Maduro was pelted with objects by angry protesters as he left a military event in the south-eastern state of Bolivar earlier on Tuesday. The latest anti-government demonstrations were sparked by a decision on Friday to bar opposition leader Henrique Capriles from holding public office for 15 years. The dead teenager was identified as Brayan Principal by opposition MP Alfonso Marquina, who said he had been shot in the abdomen. A 36-year-old man was also killed in Barquisimeto in a separate incident, the state prosecution service said. Opposition leaders are calling for a date to be set for postponed regional elections. Mr Maduro has resisted efforts by the opposition to hold a referendum on removing him and has vowed to continue the "socialist revolution" launched by his predecessor Hugo Chavez. He says the economic crisis and efforts to get rid of him are a capitalist conspiracy.
MGT:
Caracas, Venezuela - A teenage demonstrator was killed Wednesday during escalating protests across Venezuela, fueling further outrage amid the nation's deepening political and economic crisis. The circumstances surrounding the death are under investigation, but witnesses report the teen was fatally wounded during clashes with security forces in the capital.

The tragic incident occurred as thousands took to the streets to voice their discontent with the current government's handling of the country's economic woes, marked by hyperinflation, widespread shortages of food and medicine, and a breakdown in public services. Opposition leaders are calling for immediate elections, accusing the ruling party of clinging to power through undemocratic means.

Government officials, however, have condemned the protests as violent and destabilizing, alleging they are part of a foreign-backed plot to overthrow the legitimate government. State media outlets have highlighted incidents of property damage and attacks on law enforcement officers, portraying the demonstrations as chaotic and dangerous.

International organizations have expressed concern over the rising tensions and the use of force against protesters. Calls for dialogue and a peaceful resolution to the crisis are growing, with many urging both the government and the opposition to engage in constructive negotiations to address the country's pressing issues. The death of the teenage demonstrator is likely to further inflame passions and complicate efforts to find a way forward.

prompt: Power has been reconnected to all homes in Wales, more than 48 hours after Storm Doris battered the country.
HWT: Scottish Power said it reconnected the last of the homes, all on Anglesey, at about 19:00 GMT on Saturday. About 600 engineers had been drafted in to restore supplies after 80,000 properties originally suffered power cuts. Vans had provided hot food and drinks to those affected, with breakfast also delivered on Saturday. Scottish Power spokesman Paul Ferguson said there would be plenty of work to do in the long-term to deal with the storm's damage. Meanwhile, Arriva Trains Wales is running a replacement bus service between Llanelli and Shrewsbury on Saturday because of storm damage to trains and overhead wires. The Llandudno to Blaenau Ffestiniog line will be shut until Monday as buses replace trains on an amended timetable. Western Power Distribution worked overnight on Friday to restore power to 240 properties in south and west Wales, 157 in Pembrokeshire and 83 in Powys. On Thursday, Storm Doris caused damage and affected travel and power supplies across Wales. Wales recorded the strongest gust of wind in the UK as the weather station at Capel Curig in Snowdonia peaked at 94mph (151km/h). North Wales was worst affected by the storm and North Wales Police received about 500 more calls than usual.
MGT:
After a grueling 48 hours, power has been fully restored to all homes across Wales, marking the end of a widespread outage caused by the ferocious Storm Doris. The storm, which swept through the country earlier this week, brought with it hurricane-force winds that toppled trees, damaged power lines, and left thousands in the dark.

Engineers from Western Power Distribution and other utility companies have been working tirelessly around the clock to repair the extensive damage. Their efforts were hampered by the ongoing challenging weather conditions, including strong winds and persistent rain, which made it difficult to access some of the affected areas.

The restoration process involved repairing downed power lines, replacing damaged poles, and reconnecting individual properties to the grid. Priority was given to vulnerable customers, such as the elderly and those with medical needs, to ensure their safety and well-being.

Communities across Wales have shown remarkable resilience and support for one another during this challenging time. Neighbors helped neighbors, offering shelter, food, and assistance to those without power. Local community centers opened their doors to provide warmth and a place to charge mobile phones.

While the power has been restored, utility companies are urging residents to remain vigilant and report any further issues or concerns. Crews will remain on standby to address any lingering problems and ensure the stability of the power grid. The focus now shifts to assessing the full extent of the damage caused by Storm Doris and implementing measures to prevent similar widespread outages in the future.

prompt: Former Olympic cyclist Chris Boardman has spoken of his frustration that no one has been charged one year after his mother was killed in a fatal crash.
HWT: Carol Boardman died after her bike collided with a pick-up truck in Connah's Quay, Flintshire, last July. Her son, a gold medallist, said on Twitter that the family had been trying to carry on and lead a "normal life". North Wales Police confirmed the force is still investigating Mrs Boardman's death and no charges had been made. Boardman, who won gold at the 1992 Barcelona Games, said that a year after his mum's death he has seen his mum in a dozen places, "smiling at her new grandson" and even spotted her at "The Tour". He said: "It's been heart-wrenching watching my dad try to come to terms with the absence of his soul mate. "We've all had to try and carry on living a 'normal life' it's what my mum would have wanted. But it doesn't feel normal. "A year on there still has not been a decision on even to prosecute." Mrs Boardman, who competed in cycling races in her youth, was taken to hospital with serious injuries following the collision on 17 July last year.
MGT:
Chris Boardman, former Olympic cycling champion, has expressed his deep frustration and disappointment that no charges have been filed one year after his mother, Carol Boardman, was killed in a road traffic collision. Carol Boardman, 75, was cycling in Connah's Quay, North Wales, when the incident occurred.

Boardman has been a vocal advocate for safer cycling infrastructure and road safety improvements since his retirement from professional cycling. He believes that the lack of progress in the investigation raises serious questions about the commitment to protecting vulnerable road users.

"It's been a year of unimaginable grief and frustration," Boardman stated. "To know that no one has been held accountable for my mother's death is incredibly painful. We need answers, and we need to see justice served."

North Wales Police have confirmed that the investigation is ongoing. They stated that the case is complex and requires careful consideration of all available evidence. They added that they are working diligently to ensure a thorough and fair investigation and are in close contact with the Crown Prosecution Service.

The Boardman family is urging anyone with information about the collision to come forward and assist the police with their inquiries. They hope that renewed public attention will help to shed light on the circumstances surrounding Carol Boardman's death and ultimately lead to a resolution.

prompt: Exeter head coach Rob Baxter says it is "scary" that his side needed a record-breaking eight bonus-point wins in a row to seal a home play-off semi-final.
HWT: They finished the regular Premiership season on a 15-game unbeaten run, but only secured second on the final day. Until Exeter's streak, no side had ever achieved more than six successive maximum-point wins in the top flight. "It shows you the quality of the Premiership and how well we've had to do," Baxter told BBC Radio Devon. "It's still a bit scary when you look back and think. If any one of those eight successive bonus-point wins had been losses, we might well be sitting here in third and going away in the semi-final." The Devon side host reigning champions Saracens in the last four on 20 May, as they look to reach the Premiership final for the second year in a row. While Exeter have no game before then, Sarries play French club Clermont Auvergne in the Champions Cup final at Murrayfield on 13 May. "Whether we play Saracens next or we play them later, we've got to do it at some stage, so I'm quite looking forward to bringing them to Sandy Park," added Baxter. "We've actually had to put that run of games together to be where we are now, and that gives the players great credit for how they've held that together over such an extended period."
MGT:
Exeter Chiefs' Director of Rugby, Rob Baxter, has expressed concern over the increasingly competitive nature of the Gallagher Premiership, stating that his team's recent achievement highlights the league's demanding standards. Baxter's comments came after Exeter secured a home semi-final playoff berth, driven by an unprecedented run of eight consecutive bonus-point victories.

While acknowledging the accomplishment as a testament to his team's hard work and determination, Baxter admitted to finding the situation "scary." He elaborated that the fact Exeter required such a dominant winning streak to guarantee a home playoff fixture underscores the incredibly tight margins separating the top teams in the league.

"It's a fantastic achievement for the lads, no doubt about it," Baxter said. "But when you start thinking about the bigger picture, the reality is it's pretty scary that you have to put together that kind of run just to get yourselves in a position where you're playing at home in a semi-final."

Baxter emphasized the need for continuous improvement and adaptation in the face of rising competition. He noted that other teams have invested heavily in their squads, and tactical innovations are becoming increasingly prevalent. This has resulted in a league where any slip-up can prove costly.

The Exeter Chiefs now await their semi-final opponent, knowing that they will need to maintain their high level of performance to secure a place in the final. Baxter's remarks serve as a reminder of the relentless pressure and high stakes that define the Gallagher Premiership.

prompt: The balls used in Sunday's Super Bowl will be given "added security" amid the ongoing investigation into the NFL's 'deflate-gate' controversy.
HWT: Finalists New England Patriots used under-inflated balls in their victory over Indianapolis Colts. Referee chief Dean Blandino said 108 balls will be used as the Patriots take on Seattle Seahawks in Arizona. "There will be some added security just because of the environment we're in for this game," said Blandino. During a regular game, each team has 12 balls which are given to the officials before the game to be inspected. But in the Super Bowl, because some of the footballs are later given to charity, each team has 54. All of the balls will be taken into custody by the NFL on Friday after the Seattle Seahawks and New England Patriots have prepared them. The footballs will be inspected by referee Bill Vinkovich three hours before the game, which takes place at the University of Phoenix Stadium. Blandino said the inspection of the footballs by referee Walt Anderson before New England's 45-7 win over the Colts was handled properly and the officiating is "not part of the investigation". "Everything was properly tested and marked before the game," added Blandino. "Walt gauged the footballs himself. It is something he has done throughout his career."
MGT:
In the wake of the ongoing investigation into under-inflated footballs, the NFL has announced heightened security measures surrounding the footballs used in Sunday's Super Bowl.

League officials confirmed that the footballs will be subject to increased scrutiny and a more rigorous chain of custody protocol than in previous years. This decision comes after allegations surfaced that the New England Patriots used under-inflated footballs during the AFC Championship game, a controversy now widely known as "Deflategate."

The NFL has yet to conclude its investigation into the matter, but the league is clearly taking steps to ensure the integrity of the game remains uncompromised. Sources familiar with the new protocols indicate that each football will be meticulously inspected and measured for proper inflation levels before the game. These measurements will be documented and verified by multiple officials.

Furthermore, the footballs will be closely monitored throughout the game, with increased security personnel assigned to oversee their handling. Any deviation from the established protocol will be immediately addressed and investigated. The NFL hopes that these measures will reassure fans and players alike that the Super Bowl will be played fairly and under the strictest standards. The league aims to prevent any further questions or concerns regarding the legitimacy of the game's outcome.

prompt: Police searching for missing toddler Ben Needham on the Greek island of Kos have uncovered ancient graves.
HWT: The 21-month-old from Sheffield went missing during a family holiday in 1991. Following a suggestion he may have been killed and buried on the island a fresh excavation of farmland began on Monday. The four or five graves are believed to date from 1,500 years ago but police said the discovery would not hamper the investigation. Forensic archaeologists have said they are confident the search is being conducted at exactly the right depth of soil relevant to 25 years ago. The digging has concentrated on an area around a waste tank. Nutrients found in the soil have indicated human traces and a full analysis of soil samples will be carried out. Officers have said they believe the material will most likely relate to a nearby cess tank. Danny Savage, BBC correspondent in Kos The graves found in Kos are all believed to contain the remains of adults. They are lying head to toe close to the boundary of the olive grove where the dig is taking place. Work will continue around them and police said the ancient discovery was not unexpected. There was initial concern from Greek locals that this would have hindered progress at the site but I have been told by the investigating team here in Kos that is not the case. The site being searched is on land where Ben was last seen playing while his grandfather was renovating a property 25 years ago. The Needham family have always believed Ben was abducted but South Yorkshire Police are now investigating whether he was accidentally run over and killed by a bulldozer.
MGT:
KOS, GREECE - The ongoing search for Ben Needham, the British toddler who disappeared on the Greek island of Kos in 1991, has taken an unexpected turn with the discovery of ancient graves. Detectives, acting on new information, have been excavating land near the farmhouse where Ben was last seen.

While the primary focus remains finding answers about Ben's disappearance, the discovery of the graves has added a layer of complexity to the investigation. Archaeologists have been called in to carefully examine the site and determine the age and origin of the remains.

"We are aware of the discovery of potential historical artifacts during the search for Ben Needham," stated a police spokesperson. "We are working closely with archaeological experts to ensure that any historical finds are properly documented and preserved. This will not deter from our main goal, which is to locate Ben and bring closure to his family."

The presence of the graves has inevitably slowed down the search efforts, as authorities meticulously work to avoid disturbing any potential historical evidence. The area around the graves has been cordoned off, and forensic experts are assisting in the delicate process of excavation.

Ben Needham was just 21 months old when he vanished while his grandparents were renovating a farmhouse on Kos. Despite numerous leads and extensive searches over the years, no trace of the toddler has ever been found.

Recent information prompted a renewed search of the area, with investigators focusing on a specific plot of land. The discovery of the graves was made during the initial stages of this renewed investigation. The search for Ben continues in other areas of the site, even as archaeologists continue to examine the graves.

prompt: South Africa's economy shrank by an annualised rate of 0.6% in the first three months of the year, the worst quarterly performance in five years, official data has shown.
HWT: The contraction, which was bigger than analysts expected, was largely due to a slump in mining activity, the figures from Statistics South Africa showed. Gold mining saw production fall, as well as platinum and diamond mining. Workers in platinum mines have been on strike for five months. "This makes for grim reading," said Razia Khan at Standard Chartered Bank. "Mining, hit by protracted industrial unrest, fell almost 25% on an annualised basis. Manufacturing was down 4.4%." This is the first quarter of negative growth since the second quarter of 2009. In the final quarter of 2013, the economy grew by an annualised rate of 3.8%. The rand fell by about 1% against the dollar following the release of the figures, to 10.44 rand. Compared with a year earlier, the South African economy grew by 1.6%. GDP growth has been slowing steadily for the past three years as the economy struggles with high levels of unemployment, which currently stand at almost 25%.
MGT:
South Africa's economy has contracted by 0.6% in the first quarter of 2024, marking its most significant decline in five years. Statistics South Africa released the figures, revealing a concerning slowdown across several key sectors.

The contraction is attributed to a slump in mining and manufacturing output, alongside disruptions in energy supply and logistical challenges. Load shedding, the term for scheduled power cuts, continues to plague businesses and households, hindering productivity and economic activity.

Analysts warn that the weak start to the year raises concerns about the country's overall economic growth prospects. The South African Reserve Bank had projected a modest recovery for 2024, but the latest figures suggest that the target may be difficult to achieve.

The anniversary celebration serves as a reminder of the ingenuity and dedication of the individuals who worked in secret to break the enemy's codes.
